comments.text: Kept offering this dude reading material and he wouldn't touch it. Until I finally highlighted the bit in the pamphlet about violent and sexual compulsions, where it clearly says that ppl w that flavor of OCD pretty much never ever act on those thoughts, and made him read it out loud to me. Had his nose buried in the booklet for the rest of the night. Dude really thought he was some special evil or something dude no you literally just have the final boss of all anxiety disorders. 😅
comments.author: @OphanimBagels

comments.text: I used to have something where I always thought I left the door of my apartment open, even when I remembered that I physically turned the key in order to lock it. I never checked on purpose because I thought if I started checking that would just make the urge to check stronger.
comments.author: @JayLooney

comments.text: It’s true.. for someone who’s going through and healing from intense OCD and rumination (with some health anxiety in the past) , the reassurance seeking will never end. Ever. It’s a constant loop and cycle of thoughts and even when you get that reassurance, it’s STILL not enough. I think the only way to “beat” it is to accept it, to make friends with it in a way, to say ok fine whatever even if this kills me I’m still gonna live my life and you wont fking stop me .
comments.author: @EliteMotivationGuy
